title: Shiva Tandava Stotram
author: Ravana
introduction:
The Shiva Tandava Stotram is a Sanskrit hymn of praise to the Hindu God Shiva, often attributed to Ravana, the Rakshasa King of Lanka and a devoted follower of Shiva. The hymn is renowned for its intense, alliterative meter (Pañcacāmara Jati), which mimics the powerful rhythm of Shiva's furious cosmic dance, the Tandava.

Composed in a highly evocative and descriptive language, the stotram captures the duality of Shiva—the terrifying destroyer of ignorance and the benevolent bestower of blessings. It details his fierce appearance, including his matted locks holding the Ganga, the crescent moon on his head, the venomous serpents encircling his body, and the fire blazing on his forehead.

Recitation of the Shiva Tandava Stotram is believed to bring immense courage, devotion, and freedom from fear.

chapters.name: Shiva Tandava Stotram
chapters.summary: A vigorous devotional hymn composed in the Pañcacāmara Jati meter, describing the Lord Shiva’s power and beauty. The hymn primarily focuses on Shiva’s cosmic dance (Tandava), his adornments (matted hair, Ganga, serpents, skull garland), and his role as the ultimate destroyer of illusion and bestower of bliss.

verses.original:
जटा टवी गलज्जल प्रवाह पावित स्थले ।
गलेऽवलम्ब्य लम्बितां भुजङ्ग तुङ्ग मालिकाम् ॥
डमड् डमड् डमड् डमन् निनाद वड्डमर्वयम् ।
चकार चण्ड ताण्डवं तनोतु नः शिवः शिवम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
jaṭā-tawī-galaj-jala-pravāha-pāvitā-sthalē |
galē-’valambya lambitāṁ bhujaṅga-tuṅga-mālikām ||
ḍamaḍ ḍamaḍ ḍamaḍ ḍaman-nināda-vaḍḍamarvayam |
cakāra caṇḍa-tāṇḍavaṁ tanōtu naḥ śivaḥ śivam ||

translations.english: May Lord Shiva, who performs the fierce Tandava dance—with the place made holy by the stream of water flowing from his forest-like matted hair, and whose neck is adorned with the lofty garland of a serpent that hangs down—bestow prosperity upon us (śiva) as he makes the sound "ḍamaḍ ḍamaḍ ḍamaḍ ḍamaḍ" from his drum (ḍamaru).

verses.original:
जटा कटा हसं भ्रम भ्रमन्निलिम्प निर्झरी ।
विलोल वीचि वल्लरी विराजमान मूर्धनि ॥
धगद् धगद् धगज् ज्वलल् ललाट पट्ट पावके ।
किशोर चन्द्र शेखरे रतिः प्रतिक्षणं मम ॥
verses.transliteration:
jaṭā-kaṭāha-sambhrama-bhramannilimpā-nirjharī |
vilōla-vīci-vallarī-virājamāna-mūrdhani ||
dhagad dhagad dhagaj-jvalal-lalāṭa-paṭṭa-pāvakē |
kiśōra-candra-śēkharē ratiḥ pratikṣaṇaṁ mama ||

translations.english: My deep attachment (ratih) is for Lord Shiva, whose head is adorned and purified by the wandering river Ganga, who spirals within the hollow of his matted hair; whose forehead shines with the blazing fire ("dhagad dhagad") and who bears the crescent moon (kiśōra-candra) as his crest jewel.

verses.original:
धरा धरेन्द्र नन्दिनी विलास बन्धु बन्धुर ।
स्फुरद् दिगन्त सन्तति प्रमोद मान मानसे ॥
कृपा कटाक्ष धोरणी निरुद्ध दुर्धरापदि ।
क्वचिद् दिगम्बरे मनो विनोदमेतु वस्तुनि ॥

translations.english: May my mind find joy in the reality of Lord Shiva, who is the handsome companion in the playful sports of the daughter of the mountain king (Pārvatī); whose mind rejoices in the multitude of dazzling worlds across the directions; and whose continuous stream of merciful side-glances holds back the most intractable calamities. He who is clad in the directions (Digambara).

verses.original:
जटा भुजङ्ग पिङ्गल स्फुरत्फणा मणि प्रभा ।
कदम्ब कुङ्कुम द्रव प्रलिप्त दिग्वधू मुखे ॥
मदान्ध सिन्धुर स्फुरत् त्वगुत्तरीय मेदुरे ।
मनो विनोदमद्भुतं बिभर्तु भूत भर्तरि ॥

translations.english: May my heart find wondrous delight in the Lord of living beings (Bhūta Bhartari), whose shining gem on the hood of the coiling, tawny-colored serpent in his matted hair, illuminates the faces of the maidens of the directions (Digvadhū), which are anointed with the liquid of Kadamba flowers and saffron; and who is richly clad in the shining skin of a frenzied, intoxicated elephant.

verses.original:
सहस्र लोचन प्रभृत्य शेष लेख शेखर ।
प्रसून धूलि धोरणी विधूसराङ्घ्रि पीठभूः ॥
भुजङ्ग राज मालया निबद्ध जाट जूटक ।
श्रियै चिराय जायतां चकोर बन्धु शेखरः ॥

translations.english: May Lord Shiva, whose crest is adorned by the moon (the friend of the Chakora bird), whose footstool is made dusty by the continuous stream of pollen from the flowers on the heads of all the Gods—including Indra (the thousand-eyed), and whose matted hair is bound by a garland of the King of Serpents, grant us long-lasting prosperity.

verses.original:
ललाट चत्वर ज्वलद् धनञ्जय स्फुलिङ्गभा ।
निपीत पञ्च सायकां नमन् निलिम्प नायकम् ॥
सुधा मयूख लेखया विराजमान शेखरं ।
महा कपालि सम्पदे शिरो जटा लमस्तु नः ॥
verses.transliteration:
lalāṭa-catvara-jvalad-dhanañjaya-sphuliṅgabhā |
nipīta-pañca-sāyakaṁ naman-nilimpā-nāyakām ||
sudhā-mayūkha-lēkhayā-virājamāna-śēkharaṁ |
mahā-kapāli-sampadē śirō-jaṭā-lamastu naḥ ||

translations.english: May the matted hair on Shiva’s head, which contains the glowing, moon-like line of nectar and which bowed to the leader of the gods (Indra) whose five arrows (of Kama) were consumed by the sparkling fire (Dhananjaya) blazing on His forehead, grant us the wealth of the great skull-bearer (Mahakapali).

verses.original:
कराल भाल पट्टिका धगद् धगद् धगज् ज्वलत् ।
धनञ्जयाहुती कृत प्रचण्ड पञ्च सायके ॥
धरा धरेन्द्र नन्दिनी कुचाग्र चित्र पत्रक ।
प्रकल्प नैक शिल्पिनि त्रिलोचने रतिर्मम ॥

translations.english: My devotion (ratih) is in the three-eyed Lord (Trilocana), who is the sole artist in drawing beautiful decorative lines on the tips of the breasts of the Mountain King’s daughter (Parvati); whose mighty five arrows (of Kama) were consumed as an offering in the furiously blazing fire ("dhagad dhagad") on His terrible forehead.

verses.original:
नवीन मेघ मण्डली निरुद् धदुर् धर स्फुरत् ।
कुहू निशीथिनी तमः प्रबन्ध बद्ध कन्धरः ॥
निलिम्प निर्झरी धरस् तनोतु कृत्ति सिन्धुरः ।
कला निधान बन्धुरः श्रियं जगद् धुरन्धरः ॥

translations.english: May Lord Shiva, who is beautiful with the moon (the treasure of arts), who bears the celestial river (Ganga), who is clad in an elephant skin (Kṛtti Sindura), whose neck is darkened like the impossible glow of a new moon night (Kuhu) obstructed by masses of fresh clouds, and who bears the entire universe, bestow prosperity upon us.

verses.original:
प्रफुल्ल नील पङ्कज प्रपञ्च कालिम प्रभा ।
वलम्बि कण्ठ कन्दली रुचि प्रबन्ध कन्धरम् ॥
स्मरच्छिदं पुरच्छिदं भवच्छिदं मखच्छिदम् ।
गजच्छिदान्धकच्छिदं तमन्तकच्छिदं भजे ॥
verses.transliteration:
praphulla-nīla-paṅkaja-prapañca-kālimā-prabhā |
valambi-kaṇṭha-kandalī-ruci-prabandha-kandharam ||
smara-cchidaṁ pura-cchidaṁ bhava-cchidaṁ makha-cchidam |
gaja-cchidāndhaka-cchidaṁ tamantaka-cchidaṁ bhajē ||

translations.english: I worship (bhajē) him who has a neck whose beauty is heightened by the dark radiance of a blooming blue lotus garland (Nīla Paṅkaja); who destroyed desire (Smara-cchidaṁ), destroyed the cities (Pura-cchidaṁ), destroyed worldy bondage (Bhava-cchidaṁ), destroyed the sacrifice (Makha-cchidaṁ), destroyed the elephant demon (Gaja-cchidā), destroyed the Andhaka demon (Andhaka-cchidā), and destroyed Death itself (Antaka-cchidā).

verses.original:
अखर्व सर्व मङ्गला कला कदम्ब मञ्जरी ।
रस प्रवाह माधुरी विजृम्भणा मधुव्रतम् ॥
स्मरान्तकं पुरान्तकं भवान्तकं मखान्तकम् ।
गजान्तकान्धकान्तकं तमन्तकान्तकं भजे ॥
verses.transliteration:
akharva-sarva-maṅgalā-kalā-kadamba-mañjarī |
rasa-pravāha-mādhurī-vijṛmbhaṇā-madhuvratam ||
smarāntakaṁ purāntakaṁ bhavāntakaṁ makhāntakam |
gajāntakāndhakāntakaṁ tamantakāntakaṁ bhajē ||

translations.english: I worship (bhajē) him who is like a bee (Madhu-vratam) feasting on the sweet nectar flowing from the glorious Kadamba flower clusters of all auspicious arts (Sarva-Maṅgalā); who terminated desire (Smara-antakam), terminated the cities (Pura-antakam), terminated worldly existence (Bhava-antakam), terminated the sacrifice (Makha-antakam), terminated the elephant demon and the Andhaka demon (Gajāntaka-Andhakāntakam), and terminated Death itself (Antaka-antakam).

verses.original:
जयत्वदभ्र विभ्रम भ्रमद् भुजङ्ग मश्वसत् ।
विनिर्गमत् क्रम स्फुरत् कराल भाल हव्यवाट् ॥
धिमिद्धिमिद्धिमि ध्वनि मृदङ्ग तुङ्ग मङ्गल ।
ध्वनि क्रम प्रवर्तित प्रचण्ड ताण्डवः शिवः ॥

translations.english: Victorious is Lord Shiva, whose fierce Tandava dance is set in motion by the succession of majestic and auspicious sounds ("dhimi dhimi dhimi") emanating from the Mṛdaṅga drum, while the fire on His terrifying forehead blazes with the sequential breaths of the great snakes whirling swiftly in the sky (like clouds).

verses.original:
दृषद्विचित्र तल्पयोर् भुजङ्ग मौक्तिक स्रजोर् ।
गरिष्ठ रत्न लोष्ठयोः सुहृद् विपक्ष पक्षयोः ॥
तृणार विन्द चक्षुषोः प्रजा मही महेन्द्रयोः ।
समं प्रवर्तयन् मनः कदा सदाशिवं भजे ॥
verses.transliteration:
dṛṣad-vicitra-talpayōr-bhujaṅga-mauktika-srajōr |
gariṣṭha-ratna-lōṣṭayōḥ suhṛd-vipakṣa-pakṣayōḥ ||
tṛṇāra-vinda-cakṣuṣōḥ prajā-mahī-mahēndrayōḥ |
samaṁ pravartayan manaḥ kadā sadāśivaṁ bhajē ||

translations.english: When shall I worship (bhajē) the eternally benevolent Lord (Sadashiva), who views with equal mind (samaṁ pravartayan manaḥ) a multicolored stone and a soft bed, a snake garland and a pearl necklace, a valuable jewel and a lump of clay, the friendly side and the enemy side, a blade of grass and a lotus eye, and common people and the great emperor?

verses.original:
कदा निलिम्प निर्झरी निकुञ्ज कोटरे वसन् ।
विमुक्त दुर्मतिः सदा शिरः स्थमञ्जलिं वहन् ॥
विमुक्त लोल लोचनो ललाट भाल लग्नकः ।
शिवेति मन्त्रमुच्चरन् कदा सुखी भवाम्यहम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
kadā nilimpā-nirjharī-nikuñja-kōṭarē vasan |
vimukta-durmatiḥ sadā śiraḥ-stham-añjaliṁ vahan ||
vimukta-lōla-lōcanō lalāṭa-bhāla-lagnakaḥ |
śivēti-mantram-uccaran-kadā sukhī bhavāmyaham ||

translations.english: When shall I become truly happy (kadā sukhī bhavāmyaham) by residing in a cave near the celestial river (Ganga) forest, with my evil thoughts banished, holding my folded hands above my head, concentrating my wavering sight on the forehead of Lord Shiva, and continually chanting the mantra "Śivēti" (Shiva)?

verses.original:
निलिम्प नाथनागरी कदम्ब मौल मल्लिका ।
निगुम्फ निर्भक्ष्णिका मधुनिका मनोहरः ॥
तनोतु नो मनोमुदं विनोदिनी महेसः ।
परिश्रय परं पदं तदालये स्थितः ॥
verses.transliteration:
nilimpā-nāthanāgarī-kadamba-maula-mallikā |
niguṁpha-nirbhakṣṇikā-madhunikā-manōharaḥ ||
tanōtu nō manōmudaṁ vinōdinī mahēsaḥ |
pariśraya paraṁ padaṁ tadālayē sthitaḥ ||

translations.english: May the great Lord (Maheśa), whose captivating garland of Kadamba and Mallikā flowers worn by the celestial city dwellers (Nāthanāgarī) is destroyed by the flow of honey, grant delight to our minds. May he who resides in his own abode and is the source of all joy grant us the Supreme State.

verses.original:
प्रचण्ड वाडवानल प्रभा शुभप्रचारिणी ।
महाष्ट सिद्धि कामिनी जनावहूत जल्पना ॥
विमुक्त वाम लोचना सवधू निकृत वल्लरी ।
समप्रवृत्त दहनः कदा सदाशिवं भजे ॥

translations.english: When shall I worship (bhajē) the eternally benevolent Lord (Sadāśiva), whose glorious power spreads like the great submarine fire (Vāḍavānala), whose divine attendants (Kāminī) possess the eight great powers (Mahāṣṭa-Siddhi) and engage in joyful chatter, and who is engaged in the equal destruction (Dahana) of the world?

verses.original:
इमं हि नित्यमेवमुक्तमुत्तमोत्तमं स्तवम् ।
पठन् स्मरन् ब्रुवन् नरो विशुद्धिमेति सन्ततम् ॥
हरौ गुरौ सुभक्तिमाशु याति नान्यथा गतिः ।
विमोहनं हि देहिनां सुशङ्करस्य चिन्तनम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
imaṁ hi nityamēvamuktam-uttamōttamaṁ stavam |
paṭhan smaran bruvan narō viśuddhimēti santatam ||
harau gurau subhaktim-āśu yāti nānyathā gatiḥ |
vimōhanaṁ hi dēhināṁ suśaṅkarasya cintanam ||

translations.english: By continuously reciting, remembering, and narrating this highly excellent hymn (Stavam), a person attains constant purification (Viśuddhim). They quickly attain great devotion to the Lord (Hari) and Guru; there is no other path. Indeed, contemplation of the auspicious Shankara removes the delusion (Vimohanaṁ) of embodied beings.

verses.original:
पूजावसान समये दशवक्त्र गीतम् ।
यः शम्भु पूजन परं पठति प्रदोषे ॥
तस्य स्थिरां रथ गजेन्द्र तुरङ्ग युक्ताम् ।
लक्ष्मीं सदैव सुमुखिं प्रददाति शम्भुः ॥
verses.transliteration:
pūjāvasāna-samayē daśavaktra-gītam |
yaḥ śambhu-pūjana-paraṁ paṭhati pradōṣē ||
tasya sthirāṁ ratha-gajēndra-turaṅga-yuktām |
lakṣmīṁ sadaiva sumukhiṁ pradadāti śambhuḥ ||

translations.english: At the conclusion of the worship, whoever recites this hymn sung by the ten-headed (Ravana), being fully devoted to Shiva’s worship during the Pradosha (dusk) period, Lord Shiva (Shambhu) always bestows upon them stable prosperity (Lakshmi) endowed with chariots, magnificent elephants, and horses, and with a cheerful face.
